awd_titl_txt: Workshops on Tracking Quality of Experience in the Internet
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the first of two anticipated workshops on tracking Quality of Experience  (QoE) in the Internet. The workshops will bring together top researchers in academia and industry, as well as government representatives, to discuss ongoing work on the topic, and opportunities and potential frameworks for collaboration across the different disciplines. The intended outcome is a research agenda leading to better methods to measure and analyze the state of QoE in the current Internet and identify and localize the causes of QoE impairments. Considering the diversity of topics to consider, the organizers will ensure through announcements in a range of venues and targeted email that different research areas and perspectives are adequately represented.

The term "Quality of Experience (QoE)" describes a user's subjective assessment of his or her experience using some application. Network engineers have in the past focused on Quality of Service: performance metrics such as throughput, delay and jitter, packet loss, and the like. But different performance as measured by QoS parameters only matters if it affects the consequential experience of users, as they attempt to use one or another application over the net. QoE impairments, which might include rebuffering for streaming video or excessive round trip latency for real time speech, are what really matter to the user. The goal of the workshops is to understand the state of research with respect to QoE, and specifically to contemplate a community agenda to integrate ongoing threads of QoE research into a collaboration, in order to measure and analyze the state of QoE in the current Internet and identify and localize the causes of QoE impairments.

These meetings will bring together researchers in different areas critical to understanding QoE in the Internet - from network measurements, to experimental designs and human factors - and provide opportunities for cross-area research and collaboration. The outcome of the workshop will begin to define relevant measurements of broadband quality and help network providers to better understand where impairments are arising in the global Internet. These consequences should in turn lead to a better Internet experience for the typical user of the Internet. As well, the discussions at the workshop are intended to suggest new research collaboration for the network, systems and human computer interaction communities.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this project was to advance multidisciplinary understanding and progress toward the measurement and assessment of users Quality of Experience (QoE) in the Internet through a series of focused workshops engaging leading network researchers from academia, industry, and government. Better performance measurements and understanding and use of those measurements is important to support better network design, informed decision-making by Internet users, and evidence-based Internet policymaking. Better data, metrics, and measurement infrastructure are needed to ensure high quality service in the Internet. The design of those measurement strategies is complex because the services and technologies used to support those are complex and continuously evolving.

Two workshops were organized. A first workshop was hosted at Princeton University in October 2015 that focused on the general challenges associated with measuring QoE, which depends jointly on users' subjective evaluation of their experience when using particular Internet applications and the end-to-end Quality of Service (QoS) of the network services that enable those applications. An important assessment challenge relates to the desire to identify the source of QoE impairments, a problem rendered difficult by the many factors and stakeholders responsible for factors that contribute to the overall user's end-to-end experience and the heterogeneity in user behaviors, network and service configurations, and strategic incentives of the relevant stakeholders. The workshop was jointly sponsored by the FCC and the NSF and the participants included an international assemblage of leading network researchers from academia and industry.

In July 2018, a second workshop was hosted at MIT that focused on the methods, metrics, and challenges for assessing the performance of gigabit (high speed) broadband networks. Performance of the broadband services that support Internet applications is a key determinant of users' QoE in the Internet. This workshop assembled many of the same leading academic, industry, and government researchers as attended the first workshop, along with other researchers focused on broadband performance measurement issues. A goal of this workshop was to provide a level-setting and networking opportunity among representatives of many of the leading research and operational efforts within academia, industry, and the government to collect, analyze, and make use of broadband and Internet performance measurement data and in the design of the measurement methods and tools.

Both workshops contributed to expanding the collective understanding and cross-disciplinary and institutional engagement among leading network researchers from academia, industry, and government. Building these connections and promoting common understanding across scholars from different vantage points has contributed to advancing Internet performance measurement efforts in the U.S. and abroad.
